Clear amber coloured beer with a small white head and no carbonation. A malty roasted aroma. Full creamy palate. Finish is herby yeasty with a bitter ending. Nice one.
brown coloured body with a off white head a spicy fruity malty aroma a spicy malty herby fruity sweet taste with a sweet alcholic fruity bitter finish

Bottle provided by thirdeye11.

Pours a brown color with a white head. Aroma is yeast and Belgian candi sugar. You also get some caramel. The flavor is caramel with a lot of malted sweetness. The alcohol is definitely present. Medium carbonation and extremely drinkable, even for 9.5 percent ABV.
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  poured a cloudy amber with an off white head.  aroma and flavor were both olives, tartness, and cinnamon.

750.  Pours a hazy light brune body with an off white mineral speckled head.  Yeast y body with fruit highlights, plum, caramel, raisins, and a modest warming.  Chewy and well spiced Trappist ale and a delicious quad.

25 and 2/5 ounce bottle. Pours a murky brown with a small tan head. Aroma is creamy, malty, yeasty, and bready. Buttery also, with slightly spoiled dairy - I love it. Flavor repeats the aroma and adds a dark grape essence. The butter is present again with force. Alcohol is pretty apparent for under 10%. Upper-medium viscosity, chewy palate. Overall, very good.
2002 edition. Amber, brown colored brew. Malty aroma, dried fruits. Flavor is malty, some dried fruits, a bit sweet, brown sugar. Very drinkable and enjoyable.
Pours a darkish red/brown. Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol. Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit. Also has strong hints of spice.
bottle, thanks to thirdeye11, amber brown pour with light foam, aroma of caramel and nuts, flavors of caramel, aged fruit and nutty, finish was a little light
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  deep amber off white head.  alcohol, dried fruits and caramel.  caramel, dried fruits, alcohol and a yeasty finish.

Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11.  Hazy orangeish amber pour. Smell has a woody grapefruit side to it. Some tart as well. Taste has a fruity flavor that is mixed well with the wood. Different aftertaste that lightly remains in the back of the throat.
750 ml bottle a very dark brown colored beer with a beige head aroma of roasted malts some spices sweetness and hop taste dry fruit, sweetness and spices and a bitter finish

Botella. Quite alive when opened... deep dark brown colour, head died right away like pouring a Sprite. Sweet roasty bit sour dark fruity aroma. Fair mouthfeel. The flavour has lots of roasty malt with dark fruits, yeast and some sourness.

Bottle shared by Andy in St. Louis, purchased at Wine and Cheese Place.  Pours a cloudy brown/plum color with a small white head.  Big raisin aroma, with notes of brown sugar, Belgian yeast, sherry, wood, and a touch of hops.  Flavor is also led by raisins, with brown sugar, yeast, wood, sherry, sweet malts, caramel, and warming alcohol.  Medium-full bodied, good level of carbonation, and smooth.  Really nice beer.
Rich dark amber/copper pour. Dried fruit, yeast, sugar and some honey aromas. Flavor is sweet and fruity nice yeast and brown sugar too.

750ml bottle, pours a mostly clear dark amber with a good sized off-white head that leaves nice sheets of lace.  Aroma is nice lightly spiced yeast, candied and overripe dark fruits, and a little caramel.  Flavor is a nice blend of the spicy yeast and dark fruits.  Theres just enough of both to balance this out very well without turning overly sweet or spicy.  Good stuff and easy drinking, but not as much complexity as some of the top Quads.

Bottle dated use by 9/09. Poured q mahogany caramel cloudy color. Nose was yeasty with typical candied sugars. Flavor is classic Belgian. Ive had this many times and it is definitely a favorite of mine just never got around to rating it. Great depth of fllavor. Some fruit notes and some sweetness with a great malt yeast balance. Excellant.
Bready candy caramel Belgian aroma. Small head, brown and murky. Not too sweet, smooth malty dark fruity raisin.

75cl bottle shared with my father
hazy brown, offwhite or light brown head.
aroma ofdark fruits, raisins, and spices.
overall mild aroma, well blended.
flavor is fiant dark fruits, licorice, alc. much more potent flavor than aroma.
overall a well blended belgian, but alc seems to be perhaps a little bit too high for the brew.

750 mL bottle at St. Veronus.  Dark ruby brown with a two-finger beige head.  Aroma is quite spicy, with some caramel, prunes, and candi-sugar. UPDATED: JAN 3, 2010 750ml bottle. My bottle may have been a bit off, but I was not hugely impressed. Pours hazy dark brown with frothy tan head. Great aromas of plums, yeast and spice. Flavour is complex, with dark fruits, toffee sweetnes, with creamy body. Lingering bitterness in the finish not too enjoyable.

Small gusher upon opening the chilled bottle. Dark, nutty toffee aromas.  Flavor is just perfectly lightly sweet with roasted hazelnut notes.  Vivid carbonation and fine bubbles coat the tongue.  This is stellar.

Big frothy biege head a dark ruby red plum like pour,aroma dark fruit yeast wine cherry spice,plum,flavour yeast raisin,port wine,liccorice,bitter very smooth,a nice tangy fizz,sweetness,plum,prune,creamy note candy,strong flavours throughout,delicious Bruin,good caramel flavour,finish smooth but strong flavours a creamy touch,bitter fizz.

Bottle. A real gusher which poured dark copper with a beige head that lasts well. Aroma is a nice combination of sweet and sour notes: ripe berries (raspberries, blueberries), malt, dark fruits (raisins, prunes), blackcurrant and toffee. Flavour goes along similar lines although the sweetness is kept well in check by the more bitter notes as well as the addition of some subtle vinous notes into the mix. Light to medium body but with a long dry finish and the alcohol very well hidden, this is a very well constructed, well balanced quad that can hold its own with the best of them.

750 ml bottle from a KW group private order. pours clear garnet with a small tan head and minimal carbonation. aroma of dark belgian malt and candied sugar with a touch of yeast. the flavour startswith some dark malt and then there is a delicious candy middle, then finish is sweet but rounded. its out standing soft in the mouth, almost delicate. its super easy to drink and all around is a very enjoyable brew.

750 ml bottle thanks to kryptic shared with a few friends. A bit of a gusher, and drank pretty much room temperature. Pours a deep brown color with a thick beige head. The aroma is lots of yeast, fruits and sweet candies. The flavor is rich and impressive; loads of yeast and sweet Belgian candies, lots of fruit, prunes and plum, a nice creamy mouthfeel. Quite drinkable. Nice.
Thanks Secret Santa!  Sunny reddish brown, strong fluffy head.  Woodsy raspberry aroma, mild, raisin and prune, building heat and a jammy finish.  Went back 1 or 2 times to take another sample.
Very nice beer, but not that special... Maybe it will be better when I wait a few years before drinking it.
Very good trappist from the Achel brewery, much better than the regular Achel 8 Bruin. Sweet aroma and a wonderfull mellow and cottonmouth aftertaste/afterfeeling.

Bottle. Brown almost coke looking pour. Sediment was more than normal. Aroma was sweet and of dried fruit. Very easy to drink and has a balanced flavor which isnt too sweet and has a great aftertaste. Alcohol is hidden exceptionally. Great Beer.

Muddy brown color with small yeast sediments, one finger wide creamy off-white head.
Quite powerful aroma of rye bread, alcoholic figs, dark grapes, vanilla, banana, spicy herbs and so on...
Quite similar flavor to the St. Bernardus Abt 12. Oily, rich texture with soft, but lively carbonation.
Vinous character both in the aroma and the flavor. Balanced body with medium alcohol level. Slight okaed tawny port  character as well in the background.
Ive also detected some moderate tannic acid notes at the medium. Not as complex as the Top 3 Abts, but highly recommendable.

bottle, pours dark reddish brown with a medium tan head.  Prune and dark cherry mixes with yeast and candy sugar in the nose.  Sweet malt, cinnamon and a light boozy finish that has some yeast and sweetness that lingers on.  Mouth is light to medium bodied with a moderate carbonation.  Very satisfying.

Pours deep hazy brown with beige head. Aroma is heavenly - herbal, crisp, light spices, some very light basementy yeast, some slight vinuous port-like notes in the background. Flavor is lightly sweet, mildly sharp acidic notes, vanilla, a little syrupy in the palate, mild bitterness developing at the end. Impressive, very well constructed abt from start to finish.

Bottle. Large creamy light brown head with fair lacing. Brown body heavily particulate. Heavy malt aroma of caramel,, toffee and nutty, brown sugar as well. Full body sticky texture. Heavy sweet and light bitter. Powerfull A nice beer, very good and well balanced.

750mL bottle from a group order. I wish Id ordered more. Pours a murky dark brown with a large tan fluffy head that is just perfect. The nose on this is very impressive. Apples, grapes, prunes, berries, yeast, candi sugar, malty complexity, creamy Belgian Trappist awesomness. Defines enticing. Flavour comes in waves, and is spectacular. Candi sugar upfront makes way for so many different fruity and malty elements theyre hard to fully put into words. Every sip its something different. Mouth-feel is just perfect, full and rich, creamy. Alcohol is not noticable. Perhaps a little port/sherry character to it. A little earthy from the well hidden hop characteristics. I really am loving the yeast signature here. Just scrumtralescent stuff. Let this baby warm up while you drink it to fully open up and reveal its awesomeness. Refined and sophisticated, one of the best Ive ever had.
Strong, complex, lots of iron taste, plenty of floaters in the bottom... Achels best. Knocked me out for hours.

Bottle. Cloudy orangey and dark amber with a good off-white head. Lots of orange zest aroma. Flavour is more enjoyable with a good mix of caramel, but also some citrussy freshness. Quite spicy, yet well-balanced sweetness. Medium body, hiding well its strength. Nice.
Bottle. Pours brown colour with a nice beige head. Aroma and flavour of dark fruit, malt, chocolate, yeast, hops and sugar.

Bottle that I picked up from Dranken Geers, Oostakker, Gent, Flanders early March 09, consumed 04-05-09   Pours brwon in colour, touch murky with a light beige head. Aroma is of dark sticky fruits, bit figgy and prunes, touch of yeast and some candy sugar. Taste is warming, a little too sweet, dark sticky fruits show again, some silky milky chocolate, nice maltiness and a little nutty. This is a very nice beer but to be honest not quite as good as I had anticipated.  A7 A4 F7 P4 Ov14   3.6
poured amber. spicy, dusty, cellar-y beer. Dark fruits, raisin, candy sugar. Excellent beer. Thanks sebletitje.

pours copper, thin white head.
Aroma and taste, dark fruits, yeasty, tart cherries with some prune and figs, light vinous mouthfeel, dark candi sugar.
Colore ambrato un pò torbido,schiuma spessa e beige.Aroma di malto tostato e di caramello.In bocca è complessa,dolce e piccante assieme.Ottima
happy to not only try another Achel but add another trappist to my list... light cloves, soil, sugar, dry old fruits ... big cream head .. brown and tasty .. shows a tad of its heat ... enjoyable!

Bottle (Best buy 1/2009. Perhaps a bit past its prime) Pours a rusty brown/amber- good effervescence with a large bubbly tan head. Very elegant aroma- soft Belgian yeast with some musty phenols- some cocoa, rich yet soft toffee from dark Belgian malts and a touch of dates. Fluffy carbonation covers a slick and warming body. The flavor gives off some cocoa and date sweetness- however, its soft and not astringent like some Quads. It does have some warming alcohol (only in the feel, not the flavor) Perhaps some raisin and fig with a gritty dark malt note on the back. Well crafted and a good example, however, it falls short of the top examples of Quads (Rochefort, Westy).

750ml Bottle:  Sweet aroma of raisins, dark ripe fruits, slight funk, caramel, candi sugar, malts, and plums.  Poured light brown/amber in color with a small, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of medium-and large-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of malts, caramel, dark ripe fruits, light nuts, plums, raisins, and figs.  Medium body.  Slightly tingly, lightly sticky texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Average to lively texture.  Sweet, malty, nutty finish.

POurs a dark amber-brown with a nice thick head & lacing. Fantastic aroma - so pungent and dark, fig, sour cherry. Wow! Perfectly balanced taste - sweet dark caramel, butter-tart, gingerbread. Thick and creamy body - nice and tasty and perfectly carbonated. Love it! Not too bitter, nice and sweet with light spice.
Bier Koning. Dark brown body with thick head. Malty nose, with dark fruits. Sweet, malty and spicy flavours, including banana and chocolates. Well-balanced and rich. Warming. Very good.

750 ml bottle.  Deep brown coloured beer with a lovely thick creamy brown head.  Rich malty aroma, lots of plums and prunes as well as a lot of big figgy malts.  There is a big clove and cinnamon spiciness in addition to some very faint banana and a bit of apricot as well.  Loads of delicious dried fruits and a lightly vineous tartness as well.  Flavour is really tasty.  Dark toasty malts, some light rum and dried dates along with a bit of tart cherry flavour.  Warming really brings out a lot of great characteristics in this brew.  Rich chocolate, cocoa, earthiness and tobacco in addition to all of the dried fruitiness that was mentioned above.  Somewhat unusually, it seems to get less sweet as it warms up.  Lightly carbonic aroma... a bit of spiciness and a touch of earthiness.  Rich and complex but also quite balanced and approachable.  This is a pretty damn solid brew.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy ruby colour with a  big tan head. 
Aroma is malt and rock candy, spices and alcohol. 
Flavor is prune, malt and yeast, but acidic.

Bottle 75cl.
Pours a murky coppor brown colour with a great size lasting head and good carbonation.
Smell is interesting, bitter and sweet fruits there, well balanced with a hint of spices there.
Taste is also a good balance between sweetness and bitterness with several fruits and spices in the mix.
My favorite style, great beer.

Bottled at Horsens Beerfestival. Reddish , deep brown body with a big beige head. Aroma is sweetish like brown sugar , raisins and plum. Flavor is sweet, roasted malt, syrup, dry fruit, spicy, brown sugar and alcohol. Definitely the best I have tasted from Achel.

Wow.  Very full, highly carbonated and quite dry in the finish, the esters in this beer dominate the profile: figs, plums, raisins, vanilla, clove, you name it.  Lots of chocolate, toffee, tobacco and even slight roast flavors. Only detracts being slightly sweet-syrupy, but this is balanced by the warmth and rather dry finish.  Best trappist version of the style Ive had, hands down.
Typical NE Belgian beer...lots of fruity flavor.  That isnt bad if you like fruity beers...which I dont.  Had to try it, but wont spend the money on another.

Bottle with Butters at the First Cellar Reduction.  Lots of carbonation.  Off white head and a straw colored body.  Looks like a volcano of bubbles.  Musty, sweet smell.  Taste of banana, dark fruit, and alcohol.

Pours with a huge foamy lightly tan head and a hazy amber hued body with some floaties. Good lace and retention. Aroma of sherry, berries, jam, brandy, strawberry, candi sugar and lots of alcohol. Taste is very yeasty with dark fruits, dry sherry and dried figs. Quite bitter in the finish with a good amount of alcohol. Sort of creamy mouthfeel, but not great for the style. Also a bit too fizzy.

Murky brown with a viscous, lingering  tan head. Earthy yeasty aroma with brown sugar and medium roast malts. Frothy mouthfeel with a tongue stinging twang. Earthy, yeasty dry brown malt flavors with some brown sugar. Really sweetens up as it warms.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours dark redish brown, dark fruits, malty, caramel, little yeast, little spice.

Pours deep brown with some red in it. Huge meringue like tan head that leaves substantial chunks of lacing as it retreats down the glass. Nose is dried fruit and sweet malt. The flavor begins plum like with a slight bitter mid and a toffee and caramel sweet finish. Creamy on the palate.
Typical dubbel, dark and cloudy, slightly sweet but complex, with caramel overtones.  A notch above the standard Achel Bruin.
had at Beer bistro, big grape nose and flavor!!! sweet and malty almost candy like the alcohol is well matched, yummy beer
Bottiglia da 75cl smezzata allIrish Pub; complessa, dolce e piccante, lideale per accompagnare la fonduta che ha mangiato qualcuno di mia conoscenza (che bona).

purs a deep ruby color.  very carbonated with large bubbles.  alcohol is immediately present an dcontinues to mid palate.  finish is very dry and peppery.  a slightly bitter mouthfeel - may be from too much carbonation.  not a lot of complex flavors - lacks typical sugar taste and dried fruits. Nothing spectacular in my opinion

750ml bottle, 2004 vintage.  Foam began oozing out of the bottle before I could even fully remove the cap; apparently the initial carbonation is frequently substantial with this beer, though.  Fruity, sweet aroma, malty and liberally dosed with yeast, displaying hints of milky, creamy chocolate, red grape, earth, coriander, hazelnut, spice, faint berry and some dusty cobwebs in the background.  Dark brown in color, quite hazy and sedimented, with a lasting, pale tan head and a fine pattern of lace behind it.  Flavor is abundantly sugary and sweet, dark caramel and toffee can be found throughout, along with the less forceful characters of red wine, clove and cocoa, finishing with a blend of peppery alcohol, fruity tartness, mild bitterness, old wood, licorice and tobacco.  Smooth yet active and lightly acidic and warming on the palate, body is richly full.  Aged a bit longer than intended, perhaps, but retains plenty of intrigue and depth, it appears.  Absolutely recommended, and I look forward to comparing to a somewhat younger version.

Dark brown beer with a thick brown head which last for long. The aroma is malty with notes of cherrys. The flavor is sweet with notes of berries and nuts. The alcohol is hidden by the sweetness but in the finale I taste the bitternes
Sommerhus. Pours a clear brown with with a small off-white head. Sweet with a yeasty dryness. Some malty aromas. Mellow aromas of prunes and raisins. Dry finish with hints of alcohol. OK

0,75 l bottle from Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Deep brown body with a brief and stable beige head.  Complex, spicy aroma of roasted malts, dried and wild fruits, some esters. Smooth mouthfeel with a delicious texture, flavor of spices, dried fruits (plum, raisins and wild fruits), rosated grains, a bit of alcohol. Nice, strong personality.

330 ml bottle - spotty white head and glowing amber-brown; mostly clear; aromas of dates, fruit soap and slight spice; very tart, funky and sweet; up to par with Westy 12 in terms of flavor, but texture is not quite there; sweet, resin and raisin aromas; a little too sweet for me too; very nice, but not that impressed at the same time

75cl Bottle @ KBF in Geel. Darkbrown beer, tan head. Aroma was not quite what I expected, a bit faint, malts, some dark fruits and something off. Flavour was a whole lot better, lots of caramel/brown sugar, dark fruits (plums), alcohol and malty sweetness. Lots of carbonation. In flavour by far the best Achel, but the aroma needs a little extra work.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2011 750ml bottle (Kaisla, Helsinki) - shared with mjs.
Deep brown, brief head. Dark bruney aroma - its got the roasted malts, some plums, a general sweetness, a touch of yeast, but also some gluey esters which spoilt the aroma for me. Fairly pleasant mouthfeel, but a little alcoholic. Again, the brune components are all there in the taste, but the alcohol sticks out just a little too much. The sweet plum in the aroma wasnt reflected in the taste, which was a shame. Felt a little disappointed, but perhaps I had Belgian fatigue at the end of the evening. (6:4:7:3:14=3.4)
Rerate: Bottle (RBESGG2011, Grand Tasting) - as 3 Wijzen, 10% (7:4:7:4:14=3.6)
Sweet mashy grains. Very estery. More mellow than the 9.5% Extra Bruin. Good grainy finish. Sweet and a bit lush. Can play with the Trappist big boys, certainly.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 (Re-rate, bottle, BBE 20-05-2006, at Pikkulintu, Helsinki) Dark brown. Cloudy. Lot of raisin and some malts in nose. Small white head. Full bodied and dry palate with little carbonation. Raisin, malts, syrup, light bitterness and dried plum in taste. Bitterness and raisin in aftertaste. The strong sweetness was really surprising.


(Bottle, 0.75 l, at Kaisla on 2008-09-25. Shared with FatPhil and Anna. Thanks.) Brown, Hazy. Small white quickly disappearing head. Malts, yest and plum in nose. Full bodied palate with little carbonation. Malts, liquorice, dried plum, caramell and bitterness in taste. Good one, but I was expecting even more. Rating: 8-4-7-3-14=3.6

Best by 11/07  Particles really make this a smoother Abt.  A nice dark brown ale with a ruby tinge in the light.  Two fingers of very light tan head with nice retention and a nice film of lacing on the glass.  Belgian clove and slight banana esters, dark fruits and plums.  Strong malt body accented by tart fruits, dark pit fruits cherries and plums.  Finish hints at hops and alcohol, I love this one more than Westy.  The age on this one probably did some good.

It’s not often I’d call a beer in the 99th percentile "under-rated", but if any fit the bill it’s this spectacular Belgian quad. Every beer I’ve had from this brewery has been sensational and this is no exception. It’s a mystery to me why the brewer isn’t held in higher regard. Appearance: burnished copper with a shallow scattering of suds. It’s not the best-looking quad but age may have wearied this sample, which I’ve held for a few years now. Aroma: rich, sweet and vinous. American taffy, cough medicine, Parma Violets, grape bubblegum, crushed blackcurrants, sweet sherry - it’s one of those complex beasts that keeps throwing up new comparators. There are loads of residual sugars but no hint of the 9.5% abv. Palate: medium-bodied and creamy-smooth. Perfection. Flavour: grape juice, treacle, turpentine woody notes, port, cough syrup and lots of demorara sugar. It’s very briefly light and fruity at the front of the palate before a big spicy, warming finish. It’s "hot" but more restrained than that big abv might suggest. Overall: a complex, beautifully integrated quad. This is a little too sweet in large quantity but I really love the Achel house style. (75cl bottle courtesy of Papsoe. BB Dec 07. Sampled at room temperature.)

Poured from bomber, part of a Belgian-style beer tasting.  Appearance is a murky light brown, sort of like hazelnut.  Aroma is of milk chocolate and malt.  The mouthfeel of this brew is amazingly thick and full bodied; good rich stuff.  Flavor of Extra Bruin is simply remarkable:  it starts out with intense milk chocolate, with some vanilla, caramel, and brown sugar.  A veritable desert in a bottle!  Mid-palate and finish feature a more prominent rich, woody flavor while remaining firm on the milk chocolate note.  Finishes with a touch of alcohol, just to let you know this beer has over 9% ABV.

Dark brown colored with hazy appearance. Medium sized beige head. Aroma is strongly sweet and sugary with some spices and mild alcohol, surprisingly sweet one. Medium bodied. Flavor is richer with spices, chocolate, vinous note, yeast and mild alcohol. Aftertaste is sweet still with wine, some wooden note and mild alcohol. Excellent flavor, too sweet aroma.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2008 Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with lots of floating yeast particles and a small light tan head.  Aroma of sweet fruit, sugar, and slcohol.  Flavor is quite fruity (apple, pear, and lots of cherries!), with some Belgian yeast, and slight alcohol presence.  Yum!  The cherry presence gets a little medicinal by the end, but this is a tasty, quite fruity, sweet beer.  An interesting quad.

Bottle. Aroma of earth, toffee, sweetness (somewhat alcoholic, somewhat medicinal), some prunes or maybe figs. Flavor similarly has it’s ups and downs. Some nice fruitiness, some odd medicinal sweetness, some nice earthiness, some sugar. A bit thin. Interesting, decent, but a little all over the place for great.

75cl bottle.  Cherry, prune, and malt aroma - smells absolutely delicious.  Cloudy dark brown-red color with explosively big tan head.  Smooth lightly sweet raisin/cherry malt flavor with vinous notes.   Expertly balanced - only the slightest hint of the alcohol level.   A work of art - I really love the smoothness of this beer.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2009 75cl bottle. Lustrous body on the pour, great to the eye with compact, durable enough head and some lacing., Luscious notes of plum, honey and hop to the nose. Generous mouthfeel, undertones of syrup and date, with a hint of sourness. Very decent ale.

Thanks for sharing, Gregis. The body was dark brown and rusty red with a kahki head. The aroma was sweet pears with some cinnamon. There were also some earthy mushroom and pancakes. The taste was sweet peaches with more cinnamon. There was also some sugary sweetness in the finish. Good, but not too impressive.

Rating #900 Bottle purchased at Beertopia, in Omaha, NE. Pours a cloudy, muddy brown with a thin beige cap. The nose is of raisins, dark malt, light brown sugar and light fruity hops. Medium to full-bodied and creamy with tongue prickling carbonation and a "warm" finish. Round malt, raisins, prunes transition to a warm mildly dry finish. This is a very nice beer. I was left wanting more.
750ml. Dark fruits, brown sugar, molasses, spicy hops, ginger snaps. Enjoyable.

Very smooth and tasty strong dark ale. Dark brown with beige head. Big, dark malty aroma laced with caramelized dark fruit, somewhat vinous. Light sweetness checked by a moderate bitterness. Malty-bitter aftertaste. The balance there is incredible, incredibly drinkable and tasty in an easy way. Surprisingly light mouthfeel, almost thin, a bit lively. Lovely stuff.
Pours to nice brown body with a head that lingers.  Hint of alcohol in first taste  but otherwise exquisite.  The best trappist I have had

.75-liter bottle from Cheesy cheese shop, Prague (price: 230 Kč; locations around town, perhaps the biggest being at Letenské náměstí 6, Praha 7). Pours a beautiful golden amber with many visible particulates (4/5). Aroma brings up honey, leather, dirt and walnut husks, wet bark  sweetness in the front, earthiness in the back. (8/10). Ten minutes after pouring, a worm of foam has risen up and out the bottle top, now climbing out and slowly angling down the bottle neck. In the mouth, it’s sweet and nutty, rinsing to a clean tannic finish  really akin to a reduction, with concentrated, complex flavors appearing now several lonesome breaths after the last swallow (8/4). Did I forget to mention I did a full-bore, full-room spit-take with the first sip?
pours amber brown in coloration. Hints of fruit, apple raison, sherry.  pleasant mouth feel with exquisite lingering taste

75cL bottle.  Pours a medium, bright amber-brown color; off-white head with solid retention and creamy lacing; very nice pour.  Enormous amounts of dried fruits (raisins, dates, prunes), intricate yeastiness, and dense Belgian sugars; intense, generous, focused nose; no show of alcohol.  Full mouthfeel: sweet, intricate Belgian sugars and yeastiness, dried fruits (following the aroma), some vanilla and raisins and dates; intensely dense and drinkable and generous; smooth and creamy, with loads of dried fruits.  Excellent, tasty, very satisfying stuff.  Lengthy finish: creamy vanilla, dried fruits, and sweet caramel.
75cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex, but too sweet, cloudy, good head, the best of the Achel-range, a topper!
aahh so here is the reason why a tasting session with the nyc crew down at the gingerman went very hazy. Nice firm head, cloudy golden color. Yeasty aroma, with some dough notes. Heavy finish.

Sample from a bottle shared by Haukur. Thanks! Huge, beautiful head, on a dark brown, unfiltered pour. Very sugary with aroma with an eggy, celery note up front. Has a beet sugar sweet flavor finishing with heavy pils malt and a bright, inappropriate finish. Very odd and off flavor. This one didn’t do it for me, though I’ll have to revisit. Reminded me more of Chimay Blue than any of the Rochefort/Westy/St. Bernardus powerhouses.

Courtesy of and shared with heavy (thanks a lot for the opportunity to try one of the best rated quads!). Murky brown-red ody, enormous off-white head that went away somewhat slow. Sourish, malty nose, some caramel and dusty yeastiness. Caramel, croquant in the taste. Sweet, tasty, but not all that complex in my opinion. Slightly fruity. Didn’t impress me as much as I thought it would, but it’s definitely a very good, quality quad that I would like to try again.

0.75 l bottle from belgianshop.com. Poured very murky brown copper body with huge brownish head. Quite strong and very nice yeasty and malty aroma. From caramel, chocolate, coffee to some fruits like plums or grapes, just as woody spices aroma is complex. Its full body reveals sour to bittersweet flavor, almost complex as aroma with its bitter to sweet cacao, caramel and chocolate maltiness, sourish spicy, woody, fruity and coffee yeastiness etc... Long bittersweet finish is dominated by caramel and coffee in more pleasant way than it may seem. Oh yeah! Very well done brew, knowing Achel, it was not surprise at all.

Aroma is a sweet caramel malt scent with faint yeast tones in the back and as it warms a little there seems to be a bit of alcohol in there.  Color is a deep hazy amber with low carbonation and a nice tight head.  Taste is candy sweet and rich.  Starting with a bold medium body it goes down rich and fizzy.  Finish comes out with a sweet, faintly roasted malt taste with a sugary caramel back tone.  After taste is a slight fruity yeast flavor that gives way quickly to an alcohol feel.  Another great Authentic Trappist Ale.  This one is a bit sweeter then most and the Belgian yeast doesn’t stand out as much, but it is very complex and amazingly tasty.

75cl capped bottle. Pours slightly cloudy cola brown with big, bubbly carbonation. Medium tan head that settles quickly. Aroma of candied fruits, molassas and some alcohol. Definite raisons in tha flavour plus a touch of alcohol in the finish. Would be nice as a winter warmer.

Thanks to Maniac for this one. Pours a cloudy amber brown with a tan rocky head. Big peach pear aroma with hints of candy sugar and some alchohol. Flavor of molases and raisins with fruity peach pear notes. Finish is sweet with pineapple and grape. Body is surprizingly light and fizzy. Bit of an alchohol warming tongue tickler in the finish. Fantastic.

Pours an auburn brown with good tan head and small floaties.  Tastes of plums and rum soaked fruit.  Some maple syrup.  Aroma of white grapes and cinnamin raisin bread.  Alcohol is evident.  Moderate carbonation with a malty finish.

Slightly hazy very dark amber body with ruby highlights and a medium frothy tan head. Sweet fruit, molassas, caramel aromas. Big fruity flavor, grapes, apples, pears, light molassas and caramel with some light breadiness and yeastiness. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

750ml bottle, consumed in its entirety.  Pours an ominously dark brownish black with a very viscous appearance on its way out of the bottle and into the glass.  hugely sweet and fruity aroma with loads of biscuity, chocolatey malts... some toffee, caramel, brown sugar, the works.  Flavors were a very "concise" in terms of expressing the traditional Trappist Quadrupel qualities:  all of the sweet maltiness and sugariness you would expect, a whole complex of fruity esters gives this particular brew its own qualities.  A bit of alcohol but a very gentle and pleasant amount.  Palate was very rich, soft, sugary, a bit sticky... with a nicely crisp and tidy finish.  Perhaps a bit of the bitterness from the hops was evident in the finish.  A nice full, lasting carbonation that creates a perfect bubbly softness on the tongue.  My first sampling of this beer, cant believe Ive waited so long!  Looking forward to a bunch more!

750mL bottle, BB June 2007, $11.49.  Poured translucent, fiery garnet with a short cap of beige head sticking around.. a little sticky lacing follows it down.  The aroma had a warm air to it with prickly dark fruits, toasty brown sugar-coated browner spices, vinous notes, and drier, dusty yeast.. quite nice!  The flavor found berries, vinous notes, and a fuller, rich caramelization..  dry peppery spices with warm sherry on the finish.  Medium-plus bodied with creamier carbonation on the edges, but it felt a bit light on the middle.. alcohol was well masked and the warmth at the finish was rock solid.  This was an excellent brew, and it seems to age superbly.
Poured a medium brown with a huge light brown head. Very spicy and fruity aroma and a late and slight alcohol burn. Very effervescent and a superior brew.

Pours murky brown with a huge off-white foamy head.  Herbal, spicy, fruity and yeasty aroma with definite alcohol notes.  Very balanced woody nutty vinous flavor.  Plum, alcohol, fruity, varnish and some rum.  Very light sparkly easy drinking body.  Yum yum..

Bottled: Roasted malt, candy aroma, caramel and ester. Full malty flavor with roasted malt and caramel notes. Caramel bonbons, light burnt with alcohol in the end. Light astringent, dry finish whit dry hop notes. A pleasant complex, caramelic beer.

Explosive pour. Probably because I had to lay it on its side to chill in the fridge, luckily my Chimay chalice was handy. Murky brown in the glass. Aroma of Belgian yeast and purple grapes. Flavor of purple grapes (tons of grape here) and some lighter fruits with a nice dancing palate. If theres a fresh hop bitterness, Im not getting it at cellar temperature. At 18 bucks I wanted to be amazed and Im getting alot to like here, but amazing is not a word that comes to mind. 9.5% alcohol content is only mildly apparent, but it doesnt hide it as well as the LaTrappe, Roche, or Chimay, probably due to a lack of deep malt character. Whoa, just called a friend to let him know I was drinking what he wasnt and there it was, a zest of hops, about 3 minutes after my last drink. Warning: for those of you that like to leave the flavor crystals in the bottle, theres a massive amount of sediment. Im near the end of my review, so my glass looks like a lava lamp. Love it! A unique trappist that Im glad I got to try. Just not amazing.
dark brown with tan head.  flavor is nice with molasses and raisons, but lacks in great depth from what i was expecting

A little hazy red/brown colored beer, with a nic beige foamy head. The aroma is light, a little caramel and some burnt malts. Also some dark fruits. The taste is very nice, touches of chocolate, toffee. In the back prunes and raisins and caramel. A very warming flavor. A very good and great beer.

Beer number 150. The aroma is full of prunes, figs and alcohol. The head doesnt last very long. Flavor is full of dark fruit like the aroma and then a burn from the alcohol. A great beer, but not the best Quadrupel I have had.

The body is brown with a hint of orange and a little tan head and tons of yeast floating around.  The aroma is full of Belgian yeast as well with a little bit of lemon and orange and a roasty aroma.  The flavor has a lot more raisin than I would have expected from the aroma and a bit of citrus.  There is also a fair amount of bitterness.

Bottled, 750ml that was probably too expensive - upward of 16 bones.. but seeing that someone paid $24 makes me feel better. Dark brown pour that is incredibly vivacious, carbonation pushing debris all around the glass, a thing of beauty.  Off white/tan head.   Nose of candied pineapple - which probably comes from a combination of brown sugar, florals, and dried fruit selections.   Tastes like a quad with a focus on fig or possibly date.  Some alcohol present.  This could make the best winter warmer, period.  Worth the money, especially if its someone elses.  Thanks Brian!

now thats a good beer that went down better as I went along - brown with slightly white head - taste the yeast, plums, rasins, chocolate, toffee - I probably should have let this one age a little more.  Very enjoyable trappist

UPDATED: APR 9, 2008 750ml bottle(Binnys Naperville)-(Label says Achelse Kluis with a Trappist Extra label on back). Brown body with a nice tight tan head. Aroma of brown sugar, yeast, a little floral, and a little sourness. Taste starts out with dried fruit and sweetness followed by a little malt. It finishes well balanced with a slight twang of alcohol on this full bodied brew. Great tasting beer.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2008 75cl bottle from Belgianshop. Poured a medium brown colour with a small head. I couldnt notice much of an aroma. The flavour and aftertaste is very bitter and acidulated. It reminds me of a dry wine. I hope this was just a bad bottle.
Brown with a good head. Sweet and complex aroma of rum, dried fruits and yeast. The flavour is wonderfull with a basementlike quality, raisins, dades, bruned caramel and much yeast.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2008 Yikes!, liked it. Beautiful sour aroma of tart apples and chewy plum skin. The beer is fairly light, and for an abt its very light. Very similar to Oerbier Reserva but much lighter in character at 9.5% compared to 13%. The thing that keeps this beer tasting fantastic throughout the colossal bottle is the magical carbonation. It feels like drinking tiny cotton pillows filled with bubble wrap. There is a nice linger of zingly hops on the swallow and the effervescent crispness comes through. If this guy wasnt more expensive than importing a kidney from India Id buy it regularly.
Pours bright amber into a Trappist glass.  Off-white micro head subsides to hug rim leaving spot lacing.  Pit fruit and raisin aromas.  Slick with upfront caramel and a lasting dry, prune finish.

75cl Bottle at St. Veronus shared with a friend. Pricey guy at almost $24 for the bottle. Pours dark brown with a fair head retention. First hit is bitter with copious amounts of malt, dates, brown sugar and yeast. The nose similarly gave more headroom to malt and dates, with a very nice blend of sweet & bitter spices. A great brew. Not $24 great, but pretty damn good!

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2012 Bottled, pours mahogny brown, slightly cloudy with a nice beige, creamy head, mostly lasting and with an excellent lacing. Nose of malt, caramel and lightly yeasty. Sweet flavour of malt, caramel, raisins and mild chocolate. Medium to full bodied. Has a mild alcoholic finish. A well balanced beauty and its very enjoyable.★★★★★

Bottle pours a very hazy and sediment infused amber orange with a decent head that dissipates quickly leaving some lace.  The aroma is serious malty sweet and spiced and over ripe banana.  Perhaps I smell some bubblegum notes.  The flavor is very complex, sweetness, yeast, pear, peach, banana, spice, grass, honey, and caramel.  A yeast pour and warming really pump up the characteristics.  It becomes much more of a heady sensation.  There is some faint trace of floral hops that along with the yeast characteristics tries to balance out the sweet notes.  It is very balanced and well done.  Bravo.

Bottle at wine frig temperature. Aromas of caramel and mild spice with floral/fruity notes. Suggests cola. Color is brilliant ruby (in front of halogen). Head is beige/tan, but lacks strength. Medium in body with fizzy/creamy carbonation. The brain is instantly assaulted with subtle complexity. Its caramel sweet; it has fruit thats neither dark nor light (maybe this is the "dried fruit"). Theres a coffee or cacao undertone, I think. It is almost silky smooth. The finish is neither dry nor sweet; seems well balanced. There is some floral/fruity bitter going against the caramel. This is really a good ale.

Drank at home from Achel Trappist glass. Beer popped out of the bottle like a fountain. Pours dark muddy brown. head doesnt last long, but I had it in the fridge, bad idea. carmel and chocolate  taste with a great effect on the senses.

The head was quick to foam, with small bubbles near the body, foaming larger near the top.  The head dropped surprisingly quick, too.  Not too much left on the glass.  The aroma was strong to me, classic strong Belgium ale smell with caramel, sweet, malty.  The palate was bubbly, thin, and tickled the back of the throat.  The clear, but opaque brown color made me think the taste was going to be something else.  The taste, though, lived up to a great Trappist ale, mimicking the aroma with its sweet, caramel and the added hops.

Tasted 2008-01-25. 4 years old. Pours clear, amber with off-white head. Aroma: Cellar! When shaked a bit, I get attacked by port, malt, toffee and pineapple. Flavour: Very rounded and accessible. Port and malt dominates. Very complex beer.

75cl bottle. Pours dark brown with a tan creamy head. Aroma of sweet malts dominates. It has a medium body that is creamy and sweet with a touch of alcohol coming through. This is a very well done quad that I definately look foward to having again and again. Excellent brew!

Achel is a trappist, but 95% of the belgium people dont know it. 
The blond is very tastefull beer, but the brown is not my taste.
Very hoppy and malty taste, but with no extra taste explosion.

This beer wanted to JUMP out of the bottle. Nice brown quad... thick 6-7cm head pour... sweet on the nose, with the alcohol hovering just above the surface. Nice malts... light sweetness, very satisfying. I do agree that the carbonation makes it bitter. The cap I put back on the bottle after pouring the first glass almost exploded and the fumes definitely started giving a little aged yeast scent. The beer does provide a scent memory, but I hate to say its almost cough medicine, but not in a bad way. The carmel body with the malts (just that damn sugar hanging around) is tasty. Love it. Eventhe little floaty bits in the glass.(Bottle Pour 1/5/2008)

Brown with medium off white head. Sweet malty aroma with overripe fruits and toffee. Sweet flavor with hints of dates, prunes, raisins, chocolate and toffee. Very clean with perfect balance and the alcohol is very well hidden. Lovely!

Dumped this 12oz into a trappist and it foamed up so thick and sudsy it was unreal. The laceing went all the way around the glass , and the color was cloudy caramel color like a toffee. The aroma is intence pear and light fruit with a ton of citric hops and apricot. As it warms up and i take a sip the carbonation makes it very bitter and sweet with apricot  and pear. But the finish is not as fruity as the flavor i start to get more earth tones and some hints of nutts mainly almond. This is pretty full bodied and leaves a nice lasting impression.

Thanks to Yespr. 75 cl bottle. (remember these large bottles are different from the regular Achel bruin, I had my problems figuring that out:-) Pours dark brown with a red hew & creamy lasting white head that creates some magnificent curtains. Aroma & taste is of Port/vinous, dried dark fruits, roasted malts, caramel & brown sugar. Filling, smooth & warm. Creamy phat lacings. Long end. A fabolous trappist beer. Way better than Achel bruin!

Pours a cloudy copper and prune color with a thin pearl head that coats the sides and dies with very little lacing. Smells of fig and sweet malt. Taste has spice, dried fruit, fig, sweet malts. Feels full in the mouth with lively carbonation on the tongue. Drinkability is good but somewhat a sipper. Worth a try

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 Pours a dar amber/ brown color with a nice light beige colored head.  Aroma of dark cocolate malts, spices, aplle, grape and alcohol.  Spciy and carbonated up front with a lot of chocolate maltiness, sugar cane, and dark fruits providing a peppery dry finish.  Hints of raisin, dark cherries, plum and sugar cane.  Very tasty!
UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011 750ml bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $16.99 Excellent!

Green-glassed 750mL from boboski - thanks, Jason!  Sweet aroma, spicy and densely malty with some apple juice, dried fruits and berries, and light hops.  Yeasty.  Some nice phenols in there with the raisin and light plum.  Dark brown, near pitch black, with a huge, spice-flecked rocky beige head that laces and has some serious staying power.  Very sweet and very spicy taste with faint alcohol, dark sugary fruit and candy-sugarish yeast.  Orange rind and a touch of brown sugar.  Some dense plummy raisin and granny smith.  Spices are very nice.  Full-bodied and smooth.  Not quite ready for prime time, but still pretty enjoyable, and I still love this brewery.
Bottle. Average light brown head, mostly diminsihing. Clear red/brown color. Medium body, lively carbonation. Heavy malty aroma (Mold). A bit thin. Maybe i stored it too long. Do not age well.
Brown of color with a nice beige head. An aroma of caramel, spice and sugar. A flavor of sweets, dark fruits and spice.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy golden brown.  Extremely thick and creamy head, and excellent lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits, and sweet malts, complex aromas fill the area with its boquet.  This beer wants you to drink it from the get go.  First sip was a blend of fruits, malts, and a good smooth alcohol flavor.  Feeling is of carbonation, warmth from the alcohol, and a luxuriant smooth  well rounded body.  Leaves a great mild aftertaste, with a glowing warmth.  This is an exceptionally good beer.

25.4 oz bottle, BB 4/08.  Pours with a foam plug.  Leaves a tan island in a ring, murky chestnut below.  Aroma of smoked peach, toffee and scotch.  Taste is much smoother than the tangy nose would suggest.  Malts, figs and plum, some vanilla.  Dry, yeasty finish.  A light carb tingle nicely offsets the rich, medium body.  Warming.  A good one.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2010 Big brawny malt flavor and aroma that is not all sugar. Sophisticated, bold. Deep dark fruts and extremely balanced. Overall better put together than Chimay Bleue (seems more finished) and more subtle than the straight up port-like Trois Pistoles, my favorite UniBelgian. Full AND subtle with luxuriant winding finiish. Thank you Jan Primus for trading me one of the best beers Ive ever had. This could replace Chimay and I would not miss it.

750 ml bottle. A hazy dark brown beer with reddish reflections and a medium sized light brown head. Very sweet powerful aroma with fruity notes and some alcohol. Also the flavour is very sweet, malty with strong sweet wine notes. Flavours of dried fruits too. Strong body, sweetish and well warming alcoholic finish. Very low bitterness. Long aftertaste. Well done, pleasant and satisfacting but maybe this has really too much sweetness to be really great. Perhaps it would become better with cellaring, but overall very enjoyable.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2008 Pours a dark murky brown with a thick beige head. The aroma is sweet, dark fruits, alcohol, . The flavor is very dry and sweet, warming alcohol, fig, grapes, dark fruits, brown sugars, fantastic flavor. The mouthfeel is lively and yet restrained, the carbonation isnt huge but its enough to let you know its there. Wonderful quad.

The color was med/dark brown.  The head was creamy and off-white.  The aroma was dark fruit, sweet malt, alcohol, and some spice.  The flavor was strong alcohol, very sweet malt, and raisin.  The palate was very thick and smooth.  The finish was very warm.
Aug 2007 chris_o shindig   Airfix glue. Warm and pleasant. Malty and creamy and warm.
The best beer of this brewery. Full bodied good combination between bitter and sweet. A pergect trappist beer
70 cl bottle. Rich, malty sweet, full round taste.  A little edge of sourness and warming alcohol. Very good, but not in the upper league.

Oct. 2005 - Beer poured with moderate head, but very nice lacing on my glass. Aroma and taste were both earthy with dark fruits and moderate amount of spices. Good taste, not great. Good complexity, not great. A very good Belgian Quad...but no St. Bernadus.

75cL bottle, BBE 04/08.  Pours a deep mahoghany color with very dense tan foam that leaves great lacing and never quite dies.  Aroma is all sorts of dried fruits with subtle rum notes.  Big malty flavor, more dried fruits, little bit of fig, finishes with plums soaked in rum.  Very nice body, not too rich in the mouthfeel.  World class and underrated by most in my book.

750 ml bottle from sprinkle.  Pours a gorgeous dark cherry color, almost clear with a huge and fluffy beige head.  Wonderfuly complex aroma, sweet honey, molasses, brown bread, dried peach, warming spices, alcohol, brown sugar, rum balls, figs, vanilla and floral notes.  Sweet, figgy and yeasty, molasses, spice cake, brown sugar, ripe fruits and bittering herbs.  Medium to full body, smooth and easy carbonation.  Yum!
10/22/05 750ml.Hazy reddish brown with small off white head. Sharp yeasty malty with some alcohol aroma. Sweet malty with dark fruits a little thin. not as much character as the other quadruples.
(bottle at Cellars tasting) Pours amber with a tan head.  Very sweet fruity aroma, with some caramel.  Taste is very sweet with dried fruits and a nice bready finish with little to no bitterness.

Cant say anything bad about this one, everything seems so perfectly balanced. It is rich and slightly fruity, perfect carbonation...one of Belgiums greatest beers. A little age might take this to perfection.
Dark copper color with a thin head.  Slight aroma of mint, which continues into the flavor.  Very sweet malt and yeast taste with an abundantly herbal finish.  Very underrated Trappist.

[Bottle, Cellars Tasting] Pours cloudy amber with a small tan head.  Aroma is sweet and fruity.  Taste is similar and quite nice.  Smooth but a little thin.  Overall pretty good but didnt overly impress.

Name: Achelse Kluis
Date: 05/18/2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting

opaque brown, thin tan head, funky spicy malt aroma, rich malt flavor, nice spice character, good chocolate, nice esters

Bottle. Hazy brown with a ruby shine. Creamy white head that becomes a milky film. Aroma of caramel and raisins/ pruins. Very nice flavor of rasins/pruins, caramel and roasted malt, that fills up your mouth and stays for a wile. Very balanced viniousness.

Bottle. Bought @ Dagli Brugsen, Nordborg. Poured in a Grimbergen trappist glass. A hazy deep red with loads of bubbles. On top a medium sized creamy yellowish head settles nicely. Only a little lacing. Aroma is great. There is plums, raisins, yeast, raspberries, roasted malts and generally quite sweet. Good creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is great as well! A little roasted malts, (I sense some almonds?), vinious, ginger, a little chocolate. Citric bitterness and a touch of sourness creeps in nicely at the back. Brilliant!

Bottle. 2004.
Murky auburn caramel coloured body with a sudsy medium-sized white head. The aroma is chocolatey, woody, with earth and cherry notes. The flavour is a bit heavy and alcohol with notes of chocolate with a syrupy consistency.

Bottle 75 cl. at home (bought Yves Vdb)Dark brown color, with beige head. Aroma roasted malts, a bit fruits. Medium body. Taste yeast, a bit spices, roasted malts, sweet, soft. Alcoholic. 
Not bad.
Bottle at Chris_o Gathering. Ruby coloured cloudy beer. Malty aroma with some spice. Thick and syrupy with caramel malt flavours and some spice and dried fruits, a bit like fruitcake.

Close to what Rochefort 10 and Wv 12 can do, but needs a little in the warming alcoholic factor. Otherwise notes of heavy amounts of dried fruits, such as berries, caramel and raisins. Coriander and other spices, yeast, weak alcohol despite the 9,5 %. Sweet finish, which could be more complex.

Bottled - Chris O Shindig 2007 - A dark brown coloured beer with an off-white head.  The aroma is very bready and has good depths of alcohol.  The taste is bready and fruity.  Raisins and prunes.  Quite cakey and lots of alcohol.  A lovely flavoursome quad.  A beer I have long longed for, and it certainly didnt disappoint.
75cl bottle at Chris Shindig.  Brown, hazy with beige head.  Very toffeeish brune, some decent dryness on end, but quite sweet.  Not my kind of thing.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2007 A Mes rate: 
75cl bottle at Chris Os Shindig.First off I must appologise profusely to Chris for this exploding all over his new table as I opened it and my very poor reaction speed. Sorry mate. Mid brown colour with a light brown head. Extremely dusty nose with slight yeast and malt. Lovely caramel malt flavour. Seems like it is going to be too sweet but its not at all. Alcohol is hidden very well until the finish where it comes through in a rush. Heavy amount of sediment floating around in my glass. Far superior to the usual Achel Bruin. Oh and Steve says it smells of Air Fix glue and I have to agree.
750 ml bottle.  Cloudy, brown sugar in color.  Limited head.  Sweet, musty.  Tart starting impression on tongue, with fruity, floral notes.  Smooth finish without traditional trappist ale bite.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2012 bottle at home ... brown red tinge ... ovaltine malt and fruit malts with some citrus nose ... Huge juicy fruity malts, quite sweet little cherry 4.3 bottle at RBESG 2011 Grand Tasting ...copper brown ... soft balsmic dark fruit nose ... light dasrk hop ... dark fruits ... soft toffee malt 3.2 man this has to be the biggest change ive seen in a score. I want to try this again

Flaske. Fantastisk øl. Kraftig duft og smag af kirsebærvin, men på den gode måde. Varmen fra alkoholen er netop det, varme, og ikke den klistrede smag der kan komme. Alt i alt en kompleks øl, perfekt afbalanceret
scura buona schiuma note di tostato caramello in bocca morbida ben bilanciata retrogusto lungo

Bottle. Pours rich brown with amber highlights. Lots of yeasty dryness and some raisny sweetness on the nose. Rich flavor with some brown sugar, lots of yeast and a bit of roasted malt. Lively Belgian ale carbonation. Good, for sure, but not worthy of a 98.

Bottle. Ruby color with a nice cream colored head. Malty, dark fruit aroma with some earthiness. Not as strong as I would have liked. Rich malt flavor with some dark fruit and yeast. Alcohol slightly noticeable. Sme sweetness, but mostly a dry finish with lingering caramel malt and spice. Finish isnt as rich as Id like. Medium body, Lacks some complexity to make it great.

750ml green bottle.  Hazy dark red translucent body with a half an inch of light tan head.  Smells citrussy and pithy.  Tastes citrusy and roasty, as well as sour and slightly alcoholic.  Nut and caramel show up after a few sips too.  Very different from most other beers Ive ever tried.  Definitely grows on you as you make your way through it.  An interesting complex beer thats definitely worth the try and that Ill probably get again.

Big head, 
golden and cloudy, 
 quite dry, hint of hops. Quite an alcoholic flavour but enjoyable

Bottled. 
Dark brown colour, big off-white head. Cooked vegetables in aroma along with sugars. Sugar is very prominent in flavour, its pretty raw without complexity. Bit of glue. Darker flavours can only be imagined here. Sweet and alcoholic beer. Need to sit for some time longer. Big disappointment.

Bottled.
Very dark brown. Large off-white head.
Pretty sweet with a lot of alco-feel. Some chocolate and burnt sugar. A bit disappointing.
75 cl bottle. Hazy dark amber/brown color, huge offwhite head. Malty vanilla aroma with some alcohol. Fruity, malty flavor, yeasty with some hops and some alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2009 Bottle: Hazy dark red/Brown colour,nice head. Aroma of vine,grasy,lots of malts,citric,and a bit sour in the end. Flavor isalmost the same medium body, nice medium fruity finish. This is a complex beer , thats a compliment, and the another beer from this brewery has this complex flavor too .

Bottle at Concordia Ale House.  Pours deep brown amber, yeasties floating around.  Dark fruits in the nose, with lots of malty richness. Before I tasted the flavors, I encountered strong alchohol carbonation/burn.  But the flavors were still apparant.  Carmel, prunes, raisins, and other complexities.  I would drink this again.

750 at the Seattle International Beerfest. Pours deep dark, murky brown with thick, moussy, fizzy tan head. Big apple-y caramel nose. Big body but not over the top; firm carb, lots of forward sweetness: caramel, toffee, apples. Thick sweet mid-palate and finish but not overly cloying. Wonderful stuff.

Bottle @ Publick House, Brookline, MA, shared with ArcaneApollo.  Dark reddish-brown with malty and slight earthy notes on the aroma.  The beer has a lot of carbonation but its smoothness belies that.  This beer is wonderfully complex and all the subtle differences work together in perfect harmony.  I measure great beer by those I do not want to finish, and this beer falls into that category.

Green bottle, 75 cl, Trappist tasting at my place, savoured on March 9 2007; eye: burgundy, creamy head, lightly hazy, suspended matter; nose: faint odours, caramelized malt, suspended matter; mouth: creamy texture, nice aggressive bitterness, finale with a medicinal aspect to it, full body, quite carbonated, mildly bitter, slightly astringent; overall: correct

FRANÇAIS 

Bouteille verte, 75 cl, soirée Trappiste chez nous, savourée le 9 mars 2007; oeil : bourgogne, mousse crémeuse, légèrement voilée, matière en suspension; nez : odeurs faibles, malt caramélisé, fruits confits; bouche : texture crémeuse, belle amertume agressive, finale avec un ptit côté médicinal, corsée, assez carbonatée, moyennement amère, légèrement astringente; en résumé : correct

Hazy & dark mahogany body, with a dense & rocky head. Excellent head-retention. A  deep, fruity, malty and spicy aroma. With plums, figs, raisins, dark sugar, cinnamon, slight spicyness from the hops - great complexity. The taste was fruity and spicy upfront, and finished more dry with strong malty notes of vanilla and dark fruit, reminiscent of old tawny port. The balance was a bit off, with the sweet fruityness dominating. It also lacked a really distinctive character, like Rocheforts unique yeasty spicyness or St. Bernadus rounded malt-profile - or Westvleterens outstanding balance. Thick, lush mouthfeel with little carbonation. Excellent, but a bit more balance wouldve made this even better.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2007 Bottle...Simply put, this is the perfect beer. It has everything I ever wanted in a beer. Aroma, color, and, of course, a bitter taste with just the right amount of malty sweetness. PERFECT!!!

Bottle pictured on top.  I dont quite agree with those at the WBC in Chicago.  This was quite enjoyable, but I still prefer the Rocheforts, and possible the Chimay Grande Reserve and even the Konings Quad.  Brown in color, off-white head.  Sweet and syrupy, with some fruits and malts, and the alcohol finish that I love in quads.  I gotta try this again and re-rate, because I dont know that Im doing it justice after the first try.

The sweetness is very present, unlike it says in the Commercial Description.  Belgian Candy Sugar is certainly present.  Dried fruit and sherry are accurate as well.  In all, I had heard great things about this beer, but it was too much like a candy syrup.  Great for the style though.

750 ml bottle. Dark brown colour with a hint of lavender. Cloudy, but I suspect that to be because of yeast in suspension. Medium-sized off-white head. Complex aroma with sugars, raisins and other dried fruits. Full-bodied. Very nicely balanced. Drying rich aftertaste.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 75cl bottle. Deep brown creamy beige head. Sweet brown sugar nose with loads of treacle, could smell it from across the dinner table. The alcohol is apparent, but not over-bearing. Taste to match - very malty with spice and yeast. Lot of spice in the finish with a slight, pleasant bitterness. Its not too much - it seems surprisingly simple, but in fact its balance hides a great deal of complexity. It is complete harmony. Thick syrupy mouthfeel. Very more-ish Cant wait to have it again!

A part of the blind quad tasting 07 with Holdenn and Drewbeerme.  A very dark almost black color with some hint of red when held up to light.  Toasted malt, toffee, raisin in the nose.  Sweet taste all the way thrpugh with some dark fruits thrown in there as well.  A nice med to full palate with a little burn as well.  Got to love those trappists.
Muddy red brown beer with a lasting mid-sized off-white head. Sweet malty aroma with caramel and molasses. Sweet and somewhat cloying flavour with noticable alcohol.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Sweet malty spicy aroma. Sweet malty yeasty spicy flavor with some hints of dark fruits. Sweet malty finish with a spicy aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark amber/brown with a large long lasting light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of cherries, dried dark fruits, and caramel. Taste is sweet and fruity with a small amount of alcohol warmth. Medium full mouthfeel with a sweet fruity aftertaste. Its amazing that they use the same yeast as Westmalle with such different results. One of my favorite Abt/Quadruples.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2007 Brown pour with massive foamy white head.  Sweet nose with hints of carob and good lacing.  Sweet chocolate and brown sugar body with a raisin/port hint to it.    much better than the last time I tried this one.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2007 750 ml bottle. Medium-sized, dense and creamy tan head. Pours very unclear, almost myddy brown. Fizzy carbonation. Sweet malty and yeasty nose. Notes of dried dark fruits and spices. Taste is fruity-sweet; plums, dark berries and raisins. Distinct sweetish malts and yeast flavors as well. Low hop level. Medium to full body. Warming alcohol,  sweetness and  mild spices in the finish.  A powerful quadrupel, but not  top end. This bottle was cellared for nearly a year, and  will surely take benefit of longer aging.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2013 Bottle (75 cl) from Systembolaget. Pours dark amber to brown, with a moderate beige head. Aroma is full of roasted malts with notes of toffee and burnt sugar, along with earthy yeast aromas, and a light touch of alcohol. Medium bodied and very smooth. A bit on the sweet side.

Holy Crap this is great.  Pours dark murky brown with an amber tint with a rich tan head that has moderate retention.  The aroma has a good amount of caramel malt that is quite doughy and rich with some Belgium-style earthy yeastiness along with some toffee.  Medium / full body that has richness and a fair amount of frothy soft carbonation.  The flavor starts with bready toffee, thick earthiness, brown sugar and figs.  The finish gets a bit sharper in comparison to the initial taste with some sharp spice.  This continues to change and evolve throughout the bottle.   Thumbs vigorously up  for this fantastic example of a Belgium quad.  This could be my favorite of the style.  Truly amazing.
Bottle.  Pours dark brown w/giant foam head.  Aroma is citrus & malts.  Taste is fruity/nuty/spicy/hoppy.  Little bit of bitter to finish off.

Bottle courtesy of Boboski: Poured a deep brown color ale with a huge foamy head with perfect retention. Aroma of cookie dough malt is just about perfect. Taste is also dominated by cookie dough malt with some nice sweet malt and a mild yeasty finish.  Alcohol was well concealed with a nice full body. I thought this was somewhat reminiscent of Rochefort 10 but maybe a tad more light and not as complex but still very rewarding.
Bottle: Poured a dark brown with a light brown jello head. The smell was sweet fruit and hops. The taste was rich dark malt and fruit.

750 ml. bottle.  Pours a murky dark sandy brown color with a gorgeous thick creamy and frosty beige head.  Aroma of fresh yeast,nutmeg,dates,prunes,plums,and brown sugar.  Taste is a very complex mixture of dates,brown sugar,plums,prunes, nutmeg and the freshest of yeasts.  Excellent !!  One of the best Trappist beers out there.
I think i had this a bit too warm. Aroma was belgiun yeasty fruityness, candy stugar and sweet. Tastw was similar however just lacked something special.

Medium amber pour.  Very large head, spilled out over the rim of my glass.  Appears to be highly carbonated, with a cool sideways swirling effect in the glass, with some floaties.  I havent been drinking too many Belgians lately (what the hell is my problem?).  This stuff is a reminder of why I love them.  Lots of yeast, fruity malts with a sweet, rich full body. Best by date of April 2008, Sampled January 2006
This beer sits a hazy, amber brown color in my tulip.  The beer is quite well carbonated and is topped by a frothy, three-finger thick, tan colored head that leaves lacing on the side of the glass as it slowly subsides in a cacophonous mix of large through small bubble.  The aroma is quite concentrated with sweet fruity notes reminiscent of figs, sweet plums, raisins and even prunes.  There is also a healthy, bready, yeasty note here, as well as some notes of clove.  The aroma is quite rich and sweet, but without being heavy.  After a bit of time a note of alcohol becomes evident as well.

The taste has that same sweet, fruity character to it, and the body while hefty is perhaps not as rich as I was expecting.  It is still palate coating enough to make this a satiating, slow sipping evening as I work my way through this 750ml bottle.  It is definitely quite well carbonated as the beer foams up on the tongue, it is not quite as noticeable as in a lighter beer, but it certainly helps to lighten the body of this beer.

Actually at this point I think I would like it to be a bit less carbonated, so I spend the time to make it so.  The beer softens out, and becomes even smoother than it was before.  The sweetness is a bit accentuated as well, which tends to magnify the fruit notes of sweet plums and figs.  In the end this beer does not quite seem rich enough, though in its defense it is at the perfect level for me to be able to finish a 750ml in an evening.  The finish has a light sharpness to it (a mix of carbonation, alcohol, and a bit of spicy yeast character), plus a phenolic note of clove.

This is definitely a beer I am happy to have a 750ml bottle of, allows for a quite evening; it is contemplative when I want it to be, and light enough to just add to the experience if I happen to be distracted by a book.  Definitely a good beer, one which even grows on me over time; it almost becomes greater than the sum of its parts.

At Kulminator-Antwerp. 75cl Bottle, Brown-red colour, small ofe-white colour. What an aroma!! Madeirisation on top. Full body, warm alcoholic taste. Very special beer.

Thanks for Joris for sharing this gem with us in his house - we had a wonderful evening! Nice deep brown color, small layer of a head . Sweet malt nose with caramel and alcohol - intense but so yummie! Lots of caramel, but not sweet, kind of yeasty  with some slightly bitter nuts. IMedium long lasting - Great one!

Bottle. Yeast in bottom. Dark reddish brown colour with a dense beutiful head. Lovely aroma of dried fruit and complexity. Extremely nice flavour of fruit, caramel and complxity. Great mouthfeel. Big body.

I didnt have high expectations for this beer. A generic label on a generic 750ml bottle, not the one pictured on this page, seemed amateurish and uninspired. It even has a lame hexagonal shield that says "Authentic Trappist Product." Could not be more boring.

But it does say Achel Bruin Beer Extra, so I guess this is it. And it cost $12.95!

As you can see by my score, this is an excellent, though unassuming beer. Dark and full-flavored without being overpowering. It is mellow and rich. Only Ommegangs Three Philosophers is better in my opinion. The after taste is complex and lingers. very satisfying.

The head effect matches the taste, smooth, unassuming, tranquil but not sleepy.

Thought I had rated this.Has the lovely aroma of cloves and bananas.When I started to taste it I was welcomed to a underlying tone that almost resembled a citrus drink but the banana and aromatic spice overrode that.
